competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing optimization problem. Goal: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = Σ(s_n²/n) where s_n is side length. Lower is better. Target: beat 68.919154.

bbox3.cpp is the core optimizer used by top solutions. Features: Complex Number Vector Coordination, Fluid Dynamics simulation, Hinge Pivot mechanism, Density Gradient Flow, Global Boundary Tension, OpenMP parallelization. Key params: -n iterations (5000-20000), -r rounds (16-256).

fix_direction post-processing: After optimization, rotate entire configuration to minimize bounding box. Uses ConvexHull of all tree vertices, then minimize_scalar to find optimal rotation angle between 0-90 degrees. Can improve score by reducing bounding box side.

tree_packer_v21.cpp: Alternative optimizer with swap moves, multi-angle restarts, higher temperature SA. Uses long double precision. Includes squeeze, compaction, and local search phases. Also has backward propagation (bp.cpp) to improve smaller N configs by removing trees from larger ones.

Top kernels use pre-optimized submissions as starting points: 'bucket-of-chump/submission.csv' and 'santa-2025-csv/santa-2025.csv'. These contain already-optimized configurations that can be further improved.

Christmas tree geometry: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (w=0.15, h=0.2), base tier (w=0.7), middle tier (w=0.4), top tier (w=0.25), tip at y=0.8. Total height 1.0. Can be positioned (x,y) and rotated by angle (deg).

Previous experiments achieved 70.676102 score. Target is 68.919154 (gap of 1.75 points, 2.54%). Pre-optimized santa-2025.csv is at a very tight local optimum - standard optimization (sa_v1_parallel, tree_packer_v18, backward propagation) found NO improvements. Need fundamentally different approaches.

Key insight: Small N values (1-10) have lowest efficiency (1.5-2.6 trees/unit area). N=1 contributes 0.66 to score (highest single contribution). For N=1, optimal angle is 45 degrees to minimize bounding box.

Lattice-based approach for large N (72, 100, 110, 144, 156, 196, 200): Start with two base trees, translate them in x and y directions to create grid pattern. Parameters: nt = [nx, ny] where nx*ny >= N. This generates crystalline packings that can be tighter than random optimization.

Techniques to escape local optima in 2D polygon packing: 1) Four-corners (FC) heuristic - repositions items at four extreme corners to generate diverse offspring. 2) Fast neighborhood search with swap/rotate/slide moves + random restarts. 3) Adaptive temperature SA - adjusts perturbation size based on acceptance rate. 4) Iterated Local Search (ILS) / Monotonic Basin Hopping - perturbation step after each local optimum. 5) Guided Local Search (GLS) meta-heuristic. 6) Hybrid GA with Jostle algorithm.
data_findings.source: WebSearch: escaping local optima in 2D polygon packing

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for escaping local optima in 2D polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding: Two‑dimensional polygon‑packing problems are notoriously multimodal; a naïve local search quickly becomes trapped in sub‑optimal layouts.  Modern approaches therefore combine a strong constructive heuristic with diversification mechanisms that deliberately “shake” the current solution and allow the algorithm to explore distant regions of the search space.  A widely used example is the **four‑corners (FC) heuristic** embedded in a self‑adaptive evolutionary algorithm, which repeatedly re‑positions items at the four extreme corners of the bin to generate diverse offspring and to break out of stagnation ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221706003018)).  Similar diversification is achieved by **fast neighbourhood search**, which defines a rich set of elementary moves (swap, rotate, slide) and applies them in a steep‑descent‑plus‑random‑restart fashion, enabling rapid escape from shallow basins ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/
